commentBody: Fun puzzle and a new PB for Saturday!  6:07.  Nice grid and entertaining clues.

Easiest Saturday of all time!  Showing some love, I suppose.

A pretty grid, but completely lacking in resistance. Even the long answers were guessable without crosses.  Pleasant enough, but disappointing for a Saturday.

After getting over the hump at 6-down, I could finally bang out some quick answers and lay down a fast time.

Good puzzle, a lot of tough areas though faster than average for a Saturday (And I don't get the majority of Saturdays).

The east area was the tough area for me.  First seeing the Norse tree clue and thinking "How is that not Yggdrasil?" with no idea what kind of tree it was supposed to be.  And that in the same square as LEA/AGHA which is a huge Natick for me.  Also I was sure for a while Faculty was STAFF but equally sure the crossing clue was DINING so got really confused there.

Then I had SACHELS instead of SACHETS and wondered for a while what the hell SPALS were.

And had no idea what a CASBAH was so thank God for the Clash putting the word in my brain.

But most of the puzzle was a pleasure to solve and got a nice immature giggle seeing SEX TAPE right in the center of the heart.

I finished this in 1.7% of my average Saturday time. Admittedly, this is partially because I‚Äôm still working on the technical glitch from years ago that still now has my average Saturday solve time at 622 minutes, but this was nevertheless still on par with my average Tuesday solve time.

Cardiologists work at state-of-the-heart facilities.

(But they're not vein about it.)
PB. 4:54. Way too easy for a Saturday.

Well, like others, I smashed my personal best for a Saturday.  Unlike others, my minutes weren‚Äôt measured in single digits, though the double digit minute count did begin with a one.  I don‚Äôt know how people post those 4, 5 and 6 minute times.  Even on a Monday where the answers come seamlessly, I can‚Äôt read and process the questions and type my responses that quick.  Maybe the fact that I‚Äôm solving on my phone has something to do with it?  Anyway, my hat‚Äôs off to those capable of the feat.

I enjoyed this; and to answer your question, David, I appreciated the grid art and thought it added rather than detracted from the experience. I did wish there were a few more Valentine adjacent fills than just SEXTAPES and LOVETRIANGLE but that‚Äôs a big ask for a themeless, I know.
Like  Barry and others I‚Äôm going to continue bemoan the less than challenging clueing for many entries, although unlike him I found most of the longer entries interesting and engaging. SOMALIPIRATES was a gimme for me, but it‚Äôs not such a well known movie and the title gave nothing away, so I don‚Äôt think that was unworthy of a Saturday, and I enjoyed the clues for SANTAPHOTOS, REMOTEWORKERS and even SERIALNUMBERS since I had to work out whether ‚Äúfigures‚Äù were mathematical or human. Maybe LOVETRIANGLES as a marquee entry could have had a more sparkling clue but overall I can‚Äôt complain.

I will note in one of those fortuitous crossword coincidences, Andrzej recommended Tainted Grail: the Fall of AVALON as a video game just yesterday; I‚Äôm not going to say I wouldn‚Äôt have gotten this clue fairly easily in any case, but the prompt made it even quicker so thanks Andrzej!!!

Swift and sweet, and no complaints.  One for faint of heart, the newby, to foster confidence and make them see how much fun it is to figure out clues and watch them click, with the bonus of a seasonal heart to look at while they're solving.

Thank you, David!

The clue for SHAG was a bit of a surprise. SHAG was my initial thought but I thought the clue was a bit crass for NYT and my mind was, as usual, in the gutter. Glad to see I was wrong. üòÅ

SWIG and SWAG were fun as well. 

Regarding comments about CAPTAIN PHILLIPS not being a well known movie, I have to disagree. It was nominated for six Oscars, including Best Picture, and was quite a hit. But then again, maybe I‚Äôm just getting old.
And now my Saturday PB is 10% faster than my Friday PB. Gasp! üò±
Took me 47 minutes to complete but to be fair, I was conducting the LA Phil in a performance of Sibelius No. 2 while solving tonight.

A new glitch that made me crazy. I finished the puzzle, the "almost" note popped up, went back to the puzzle and looked at every entry. Perfect. Went over it again, no mistakes.  Came to the column and took the offered peek.  It was the twin of my solve.  Went back to the puzzle and looked again.  Nothing wrong.  Took two more peeks, and found nothing.  Went back to the puzzle AGAIN and closed it, reopened it, and there was the gold star.  What was the point of all that?  Was A.I. just having a bit of fun?  Does A.I. have fun?  Argh!

As others have said, this was definitely an easy Saturday which gave me a PB of 18min - a little less than half my Saturday average (though still nowhere near some of the speed puzzlers in the comments). Still, it was fun, and I particularly enjoyed 11D and 12A. 

Side note - my first thought when I read 1A (given the grid art) was GEN Z HEART (as distinct from the millennial ü´∂), but I suppose that actually takes four fingers!

commentBody:
I only look at my times to see whether my inner experience on the slog-romp scale accords with the objective passage of time.

I did this in 12 minutes.

And it felt like 12 minutes.

And it irritates me.

Because when I checked this morning it's supposed to be Saturday.

Screwing and shagging are absolutely fine (more than fine), but do you really nail someone in the US.

Sounds dreadful. 

Our household doesn‚Äôt do greeting card industry days so the reminder was entertaining. 

Cute puzzle. Thanks.

Appreciate this puzzle‚Ä¶  I suppose it wasn‚Äôt the hardest Saturday but better to spend more time with my wife on Valentine‚Äôs Day than spending an hour in a den struggling . Thank you to the creator !

Hmmm... which takes longer to complete the crossword or the Spelling Bee? Speaking solely for myself, including hints and lookups, it takes me longer to do the Bee. It used to be the XWP. I wonder if the Games department is trying to let users to play more games in their day by reducing difficulty of some games... (and increasing others? I'm looking at you, Connections üòÄ) I suppose this assumes a finite amount of time for game playing.

The red of the graphic was unpleasantly distracting during the solve. I would have preferred it turned red only upon completion, or not at all. 

Kasbah - with a K - was how the fortress was spelled when it featured in the popular video game Civilization V. Karib looked OK for the beer, too. However, when I did not get my gold star and I reviewed my grid, this was the only suspect square so I caught the mistake. It was not a nice square though. Having to flyspeck took my solve time out of Wednesday territory into Thursday, but it was still nowhere near Saturday.

Valentine's arrived in Poland in the 1990s along with many other American imports. Imagine the gray, dirty and messy reality of Poland in its period of transformation, the people often angry and struggling to survive - with red plastic hearts and bows tacked on. Yeah, it was as horrible as it sounds. The relentless, gaudy pushing of it by the media and shops (and the NYT Games too, apparently) has always put me off it. Either you love someone and act on it every day or you don't - making a show of it on a single day because the TV tells you to (or rather FB these days?) seems so cheap and forced. My ex and I often made life miserable for each other - but she always insisted on celebrating Valentine's...
Forgive me for not moving on, but I‚Äôm still wondering what happened to yesterday‚Äôs comment. I only expressed my surprise that MINNESOTAN ICE were described as polite and friendly‚Ä¶
This is the most Tuesday ‚ÄúSaturday‚Äù I‚Äôve ever done. Fastest finishing time ever. Was really hoping for a challenge!

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Plenty of answers I liked ‚Äì PARACHUTE IN (as clued), SWIG, CASBAH, SACHETS, and SIMONE BILES because every image of her that pops in my head is beauty in motion.
‚Ä¢	I love the photo album corners in the grid design.
‚Ä¢	Trio of PuzzPairs¬© -- ICE SHEET and a backward AVALON, VAULT / SIMONE BILES, and LOOTS / SOMALI PIRATES.
‚Ä¢	Word ladder of SWIG / SWAG / SHAG.
‚Ä¢	Rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap (LOOTS).
‚Ä¢	One reason I like David Karp, the constructor, is that his first 21 NYT submissions were rejected and he almost gave up, but his 22nd was accepted, and now he‚Äôs had six Times puzzles published.  Inspiring!
‚Ä¢	LOL clue for SHAG.  Clever wordplay clue ‚Äì [Take on or take down] for TACKLE.  And nice play on LINE in [Puts one‚Äôs money on the line] for TAKES A BET.

So, plenty to like for me, for which I‚Äôm grateful.  Thank you, David!
Cute, maybe, but not very interesting and not up to a Saturday degree of difficulty. I hope next week will be better.

Nothing wrong with the puzzle.

Nits to pick?
I have none.
It is charming.
Downright delightful, as some 
I'm *certain* have said already.

But...
with the backlog of Friday and Saturday 
themeless building up to two years,

Crossnerd alert! Three thoughts about the grid art: ‚Ä¢ It would have looked more heart-like if the square below EPIC was moved down one space and if the square below ETHOS was removed. But it couldn‚Äôt be done because it would have created two squares that weren‚Äôt double checked. ‚Ä¢ Here‚Äôs another take on a 2/14 puzzle design, by Mary Lou Guizzo: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/14/2018 . Sweet! ‚Ä¢ I don‚Äôt ever remember a puzzle with grid art that didn‚Äôt have a theme related to it. Perhaps there's some dude ErIK who has re-defined the contemporary sense of what's "rad" or "on fleek"?

(Plus thinking that the "December takes" must somehow involve SANTA's HOhOs.)

Never fear, X-Phile fans!  I got it sorted out in the end.

It's happened in other puzzles as well, my answer will disappear after I've entered it and moved on to another clue.

I'm wondering if it's just me....

This was just too easy.

I've put off commenting on this for a while, but I've definitely noticed a trend of decreasing difficulty, especially on Saturdays. This is supposed to be the hardest day of the week, and this puzzle was not difficult at all. I used to look forward to the challenge, but now Saturday is like any other day of the week.

The problem seems to lie in the cluing. Most of the clues were completely straightforward. Example: [Requirement of some dress codes] for SLEEVES. Not only is this easy, it's boring. This is Monday-level cluing on a Saturday puzzle.

Please, please, PLEASE bring back the difficult Saturday puzzles.
6D might be one of the best clues and answers ever.

The brain is amazing when you let it be.
40yrs ago in highschool, I noticed a large format book in the fantasy section at the BookStop (remember book stores?), with someone pointing a sword in the sky, titled "Avalon". I never bought it because it was too expensive but the image just popped into my head this morning to help me with that clue. Crazy. Cheers yall.

Hello from the mystic realm of AVALON. Somerset being the home of Glastonbury, allegedly the enchanted seat of all things Arthurian. The modern day soothsayers certainly make a fortune out of wide eyed tourists!

My grandkids are coming over today. I haven't seen them since December, so I'm stoked! One of the things the little one (now 10 years old!) loves doing with me is my NY Times puzzles. I almost forgot, and started doing the Bee, but stopped after the pangram and two words. But the crossword? We love to do it and he learns about new (to him) words. How do I explain how "screw" and "nail" also mean "shag" ?

Maybe we'll just bake cookies today.

However, I did enjoy the puzzle, and am happy to say I don't think the puzzles are getting easier. I think I am becoming more adept at not giving up so easily. After my first read through, I have, maybe 3 or 5 answers filled in. Then I slow down and go through more carefully and have, usually, about ten. And so it builds. 

I know some of the Wordplay columnists have said similar things; that at first they don't fill in a lot of words, and that made me stop giving up so easily. My brain appreciates the company.

Happy Valentines Day!

I'm getting ready to take Springerle cookies to friends in our "neighborhood"...  they're meant to be a Christmas cookie, but I have a pretty heart=shaped mold with roses and two birds...so I make these ahead and freeze them.  Today I get to bestow them upon The Chosen.  
I love the anise flavor myself...

They'll take away the taste(less) puzzle clue/entry.  
Sorry I can't send you folks a cookie!

Sorry if all this has been said in earlier comments, but I am finding them very difficult to follow with the new, now-enforced, format. Yesterday I made the effort but won't today. 

But I will vent.

First, replies no longer appeared in chronological order and so a series of replies that were made about the same time to the same thing got widely spread out by threads spinning off them. With the old format, even if someone was replying to something higher in a thread, they could quote part of it to cue us in. And even with multiple long branching threads, there was still some temporal sense in how the discussion was progressing. Each was like a conversational braid.

Second, I found I was unable to search to find interesting nested threads that I wanted to check back in on later. 

I think Andrzej had a different take yesterday, but I'm not going to try to search for it.

Perhaps every post from now on should include Massachusetts Lynn's observations about the ill-conceived forum changes.  I suggest that each day this be bumped by multiple people and voted on repeatedly to keep the sentiment in front of the editors (if they exist).

"First, replies no longer appeared in chronological order and so a series of replies that were made about the same time to the same thing got widely spread out by threads spinning off them. With the old format, even if someone was replying to something higher in a thread, they could quote part of it to cue us in. And even with multiple long branching threads, there was still some temporal sense in how the discussion was progressing. Each was like a conversational braid.

Second, I found I was unable to search to find interesting nested threads that I wanted to check back in on later. "

Or to paraphrase Andrzej and others, so... much... clicking!

This is all meaningless, of course, but it is frustrating when you rely on software for a game and the software fails repeatedly over a period of years.

In other news, I was mis-under-nonplused by the clue "Access, as a profitable enterprise" for GET IN ON. Sure, one can "get in on the ground floor", but "the ground floor" here doesn't mean "a profitable enterprise". (It means "the start of a profitable enterprise".) So I'm not sure how this clue works.

@K Barrett Here is my two-part theory. One: crosswords are more about knowing the constructor than knowing wordplay. Two: crosswords are, objectively, always about the same difficulty. That is, if you compared a crossword from 1980 to 1990 to 2000 to 2025 you would find that they require about the same knowledge of current events, about the same knowledge of pop culture, etc.

If you keep doing one publication's XW, it's going to get disproportionately easier because 1. you learn their quirks (the NYT has put more OREOs into more different types of food than an unsupervised toddler) and 2. you learn what would otherwise be inaccessible pop culture/historical. I don't listen to DUA LIPA or play FORTNITE, but I know that the Gray Lady does.

On a good Monday I can finish in under 3 minutes. This is not because I am smart (I am not smart). Spelling Bee takes me forever, if I do it, but I am almost positive that's because I don't play it very often. That, in turn, means I haven't built up my knowledge of what bizarre words the constructor thinks are valid, and which ones they don't, and I get frustrated as a result :P

It could also be that the clues have trends, and we're in (e.g.) a period where more of them are about football teams or poetic contractions or something that you happen to be more familiar with, and they will become harder when the next "actors from TV shows you haven't seen" cycle hits.

Rebeck,

Your pride at completing a puzzle shouldn‚Äôt be diminished by what others do or say.

If your ‚Äòlimitation‚Äô is limited to not finding these puzzles easier than the weekend puzzles used to be, the cure is doing the archived puzzles. I routinely cannot complete those without resorting to some reveals or Googling. And yet some people completed those routinely - but seemed to enjoy the trickier cluing. I dislike the level of specialist knowledge required in some of the pre-2005 (or so) puzzles. But from then until quite recently, there is a swath of puzzles where weekends have more accessible answers but with really crunchy cluing. That now seems to have changed.

Just my opinion. Again, congrats on your progress! I‚Äôm not sure I will ever get to the point of being able to solve all the archive ones on my own.

So I think it'd be interesting to know what percentage of those who tried it out during the many weeks of opt-in testing went back to the old (comfortable and familiar) interface.

My suspicion is that they weren't guaging user acceptance so much as testing the software for a change that they'd already decided was going to happen, no matter what the users want.  (You know - like Microsoft, Adobe, and almost every other software company you can think of).

@Lynn

Commenting functionality has been around for sooo long now, it is similarly mind-boggling why there is no edit feature here. Which again leads me to it perhaps being a technical issue of some kind, having to do with the volume of comments and server capacity or something. But still! 

That is an interesting point about being able to see more easily which comment in a thread is being replied to. I thought I had done a pretty good job reading alllll the comments yesterday, but I don't remember seeing that one at all!  I do like that! But there are other ways to approach it... 

One aspect I haven't said "aloud" here is that the comments are used very differently here in Games than elsewhere in the publication where the same commenting product is in use (e.g., news articles). Games has more in common with Cooking ‚Äî a product with a standalone subscription model and distinct community. Cooking has its own commenting format; Games should get its own, too!
